message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Metamorphic testing and testing with special values
Paper Abstract: The problem of testing programs without test oracles is well known. A commonly used approach is to use special values in testing but this is often insufficient to ensure program correctness. This paper demonstrates the use of metamorphic testing to uncover faults in programs, which could not be detected by special test values. Metamorphic testing can be used as a complementary test method to special value testing. In this paper, the sine function and a search function are used as examples to demonstrate the usefulness of metamorphic testing. This paper also examines metamorphic relationships and the extent of their usefulness in program testing.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Metamorphic Testing

Metamorphic testing (MT) is a property-based software testing technique, which can be an effective approach for addressing the test oracle problem and test case generation problem.(no content)The test oracle problem is the difficulty of determining the expected outcomes of selected test cases or to determine whether the actual outputs agree with the expected outcomes.

### How It Works

Metamorphic testing uses metamorphic relations—for example, when testing a booking website, filtering the price range or star rating and applying a search again should return a subset of the previous results.(no content)A violation of this expectation would reveal a failure of the system.

### History and Applications

Metamorphic testing was invented by T.Y. Chen in a technical report in 1998.(no content)Since then, more than 750 papers have been published by international researchers and practitioners, working further on the theory and practice of MT in real-life applications, including web services, computer graphics, embedded systems, simulation and modeling, machine learning, decision support, bioinformatics, components, numerical analysis, compilers, and even quantum computing.(no content)In August 2018, Google acquired GraphicsFuzz, a startup from Imperial College London, to apply metamorphic testing to graphics device drivers for Android smartphones.

Based on the search results, here's what "test oracle" means:

## Software Testing Context

In software testing, a test oracle is a provider of information that describes correct output based on the input of a test case.(no content)Testing with an oracle involves comparing actual results of the system under test (SUT) with the expected results as provided by the oracle.

## Types of Test Oracles

Research has identified several categories of test oracles:

1. **Specified Oracle**: Associated with formalized approaches to software modeling and code construction, including formal specification, model-based design, and design by contract.

2. **Derived Oracle**: Differentiates correct and incorrect behavior by using information derived from artifacts of the system, such as documentation, system execution results, and characteristics of previous versions.

3. **Pseudo-Oracle**: A separately written program which can take the same input as the program or SUT so that their outputs may be compared to understand if there might be a problem to investigate.

4. **Human Oracle**: A human can act as a test oracle through either a quantitative approach that aims to find the right amount of information to gather for decision-making, or a qualitative approach that aims to find the representativeness and suitability of test data and output.

Here are the search results for "Search algorithm":

## Overview

In computer science, a search algorithm is an algorithm designed to solve a search problem. Search algorithms work to retrieve information stored within particular data structure, or calculated in the search space of a problem domain, with either discrete or continuous values.

## Common Types of Search Algorithms

**Binary Search**: Binary search, also known as half-interval search, logarithmic search, or binary chop, is a search algorithm that finds the position of a target value within a sorted array.

**A* Search**: A* is a graph traversal and pathfinding algorithm that is used in many fields of computer science due to its completeness, optimality, and optimal efficiency.(no content)A* achieves better performance by using heuristics to guide its search.

**Boyer-Moore String Search**: The Boyer–Moore string-search algorithm is an efficient string-searching algorithm that is the standard benchmark for practical string-search literature.

## Categories of Search Algorithms

Binary, or half-interval, searches repeatedly target the center of the search structure and divide the search space in half. Comparison search algorithms improve on linear searching by successively eliminating records based on comparisons of the keys until the target record is found, and can be applied on data structures with a defined order. Digital search algorithms work based on the properties of digits in data structures by using numerical keys. Finally, hashing directly maps keys to records based on a hash function.

**Boyer-Moore String Search**: The Boyer–Moore string-search algorithm is an efficient string-searching algorithm that is the standard benchmark for practical string-search literature.

## Categories of Search Algorithms

Binary, or half-interval, searches repeatedly target the center of the search structure and divide the search space in half. Comparison search algorithms improve on linear searching by successively eliminating records based on comparisons of the keys until the target record is found, and can be applied on data structures with a defined order. Digital search algorithms work based on the properties of digits in data structures by using numerical keys. Finally, hashing directly maps keys to records based on a hash function.

I've completed a web search for "Software testing." Here's what I found:

## Overview

Software testing is the act of checking whether software meets its intended objectives and satisfies expectations.(no content)Software testing can provide objective, independent information about the quality of software and the risk of its failure to a user or sponsor or any other stakeholder.

## Testing Approaches

Software testing can be dynamic in nature—running the software to verify actual output matches expected—or static in nature, reviewing code and its associated documentation.(no content)Software testing methods are traditionally divided into white- and black-box testing, approaches used to describe the point of view that a test engineer takes when designing test cases. White-box testing tests internal structures or workings of a program, as opposed to the functionality exposed to the end-user.(no content)Black-box testing treats the software as a "black box", examining functionality without any knowledge of internal implementation. The testers are only aware of what the software is supposed to do, not how it does it.

## Testing Levels

Unit testing, also called component or module testing, is a form of software testing by which isolated source code is tested to validate expected behavior.(no content)Integration testing is a form of software testing in which multiple software components, modules, or services are tested together to verify they work as expected when combined.

## Test Automation

Test automation is the use of software for controlling the execution of tests and comparing actual outcome with predicted. Test automation supports testing the system without manual interaction which can lead to faster test execution and testing more often.

The search results provided comprehensive information about software testing definitions, methodologies, types, and frameworks.

Links: [{"title":"Sine and cosine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sine_and_cosine"},{"title":"Trigonometric functions - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigonometric_functions"},{"title":"Sinc function - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sinc_function"},{"title":"Sine wave - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sine_wave"},{"title":"Trigonometric integral - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Trigonometric_integral"},{"title":"Sine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sin_(trigonometry)"},{"title":"Sine and cosine transforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sine_and_cosine_transforms"},{"title":"Law of sines - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_sines"},{"title":"Bhāskara I's sine approximation formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bhaskara_I's_sine_approximation_formula"},{"title":"Fourier sine and cosine series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fourier_sine_and_cosine_series"}]

I've completed the web search for "Sine function mathematics." Here's a summary of the key information found:

## Definition

In mathematics, sine and cosine are trigonometric functions of an angle.(no content)The sine of an acute angle is defined in the context of a right triangle: for the specified angle, it is the ratio of the length of the side that is opposite that angle, to the length of the longest side of the triangle (the hypotenuse).

## Extended Definitions

The definitions of sine and cosine have been extended to any real value in terms of the lengths of certain line segments in a unit circle. More modern definitions express the sine and cosine as infinite series, or as the solutions of certain differential equations, allowing their extension to arbitrary positive and negative values and even to complex numbers.

## Applications

The sine function is commonly used to model periodic phenomena such as sound and light waves, the position and velocity of harmonic oscillators, sunlight intensity and day length, and average temperature variations throughout the year.

## Historical Background

The function of sine and versine (1 − cosine) can be traced to the jyā and koṭi-jyā functions used in Gupta period (320 to 550 CE) Indian astronomy.(no content)All six trigonometric functions in current use were known in Islamic mathematics by the 9th century.

## Properties

Both sine and cosine functions are periodic, meaning any angle added by the circumference's circle is the angle itself.(no content)The sine function is odd, whereas the cosine function is even.

purpose: Extract transferable techniques and methodologies from research papers

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors if any

todos.content: Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.
todos.activeForm: Reading triples_output.json and classifying paper type

todos.content: List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.
todos.activeForm: Extracting triples from title and abstract

todos.content: For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
todos.activeForm: Searching for Wikipedia articles for each triple

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple data

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors if any

Perfect! All tasks are complete. Here's a summary of what I've accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✓

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Metamorphic testing and testing with special values" and extracted 5 key triples:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution (the paper proposes metamorphic testing)

**Key Technologies & Methodologies Identified:**

1. **Metamorphic testing** (method, proposes) - The core contribution: a new testing technique to overcome test oracle problems
2. **Software testing** (method, uses) - Existing testing methodology that the paper builds upon
3. **Test oracle** (concept, uses) - The problem being addressed by metamorphic testing
4. **Sine and cosine** (concept, uses) - Mathematical functions used as concrete examples
5. **Search algorithm** (method, uses) - Example application demonstrating metamorphic testing

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation passed successfully. The JSON file has been updated with complete metadata including relevance descriptions for each triple.
